transcripts.text: Yeah, it's great.  He's doing this civil rights thing.  He said several times, I just want to advise you, you're in violation of my civil rights in this land.  And I said, no, you're within your rights to protest, but the language is where the issue is.
Yeah, and also you have to have a permit approved by the city manager to protest.
Okay, I'm in Moultrie, Georgia, standing on the public sidewalk.

public sidewalks holding a sign critical of governments.  expressing my free speech right to criticize the government.  and this is the Moultrie city of Moultrie Georgia Municipal Building and their City Hall.  I'm just gonna stand out here and express my right to be critical of the government on the day before Independence Day.  How you doing?
Good, how are you?  I'm Pete Dillard.  My name's Jeff.
Jeff?
Uh-huh.
Curious, what's your issue?
Just expressing my right to free speech the day before Independence Day.
To be critical of City Hall.
Of what?
To be critical of City Hall.  Expressing my free speech right to be critical of government.
Well, what, anything in particular?
No, not really.
Well, isn't that kind of a vulgar way of doing it?
It sure is.  Absolutely.  And who are you with the city?
I'm the city manager.
Oh, city manager.  Okay.  Nice to meet you.
But I mean, no particular issue with City Hall?
Just expressing my right to free speech, that's all.  Day before Independence Day.
That's really vulgar.

How you doing, officer?  I agree, it is.  What's going on here?  Expressing my right to free speech the day before Independence Day to be critical of the government.  Why is that?  Expressing my right.  Free speech.  Alright.  My name is Jeff, by the way.  Alright.  What do I need to do?  What do I need to do?  Why not?  Why is that?  I can't hear your radio.  You have to get like a, what is it, petition?
You have an outdoor permit from the city clerk.
Oh, okay.  So that's why I have to get an outdoor permit from the city clerk?
I don't know if you want to pay just to stand outside with a sign.
Can you go ahead and get it, go in there and get one for me?
Sure, you can do it.  Just go in, go upstairs, the city clerk will take care of it.
Okay, I'd rather not do it.  I'm just going to go ahead and stand out here with a sign.
No, that's what we can't do.  You cannot just stand out here with that sign.  If you're going to do it the right way or we'll have to take...

I'm not going to go do it.  This is my constitutionally protected right for free speech.  Okay.  And you've been put on notice about that.  This is the most basic, fundamental, and well-established right that we as Americans have.  It's none of your business where I live.  Believe me.  It's none of your business where I live.  Okay.  Okay?

Okay.  Well, let me tell you what I'm going to do.  Okay.  I'm going to call my lieutenant... I'm going to ask him what are my steps that I need to do in order to get this done.  And if he tells me that I can lock you up based off of this information, then that's what we're going to do, okay?

So you're threatening to have me locked up if you're a lieutenant?  No, I'm not threatening anything.  I'm just telling you what can happen due to you expecting me to be locked up.  What is your lieutenant's name?  I don't have to tell you that.  I'd just like to know, so I could talk to him too.  Or she.
She's going to call him and talk to him, and then if it goes further, you can talk to him then.
I'll get him to come over here.
That'd be great, yeah.  I'll meet him, talk to him in person.
I'm just disappointed somebody would be that vulgar.
I'm disappointed in you guys that you would come out here and harass a person for free speech.
I haven't harassed you, I just came out and talked to you.  That's harassment?
That seems like it.
Are you so fragile that that's harassment?
Are you so fragile that you don't like the word fuck?
I'm a decent person.
Are you offended by it?  Absolutely.  Okay, good.  I'm glad that you are.  I hope it offends you good and well.
Well, I'm always offended that somebody's vulgar.
Like I said, I'd rather not get in a back and forth with you about it.  I'm just expressing my free speech rights.
I think it's vulgar.  I think it's low class.  I'm very disappointed somebody would do that.
Okay, that's your opinion.
That's absolutely, and I have the right.

I'm very disappointed that you won't stand up for my civil rights and tell these guys to back off as a city manager.  I'm giving you the opportunity to do that right now.  Stand up and listen to me. I just talked with my lieutenant.
Yes, ma'am.

Yes, place your hands behind your back.

I'm not resisting.
